articles.title: FCC Repeals U.S. Telecom Cybersecurity Mandates: National Risk Implications
articles.excerpt: FCC reverses cybersecurity mandates just months after Salt Typhoon breach.
articles.content:
FCC Repeals U.S. Telecom Cybersecurity Mandates: National Risk Implications

Author: Harish G

Published: November 20, 2025

On November 20, 2025, the Federal Communications Commission (FCC) voted 2-1 to repeal cybersecurity mandates for U.S. telecommunications carriers‚Äîjust ten months after implementing them in response to the catastrophic Salt Typhoon cyber espionage campaign. This decision, driven by the Republican-majority commission, eliminates requirements for telecom companies to secure their networks against unlawful access, develop cybersecurity risk management plans, and submit annual compliance certifications.

As someone who has spent years analyzing telecom security and nation-state threats, I can tell you this: this repeal is one of the most consequential cybersecurity policy reversals in recent U.S. history. It comes at a time when Chinese state-sponsored actors have demonstrated their ability to penetrate America's telecommunications backbone at will, compromising the communications of government officials, stealing metadata on millions of Americans, and accessing lawful wiretapping systems.

The Salt Typhoon Breach: Context for the Repeal

To understand why this repeal is so alarming, you need to understand what Salt Typhoon accomplished. According to BleepingComputer's reporting, the campaign‚Äîattributed to Chinese government-backed hackers‚Äîsuccessfully breached at least eight major U.S. telecom providers, including:

  • Verizon
  • AT&T
  • T-Mobile
  • Lumen Technologies
  • Charter Communications
  • Consolidated Communications
  • Windstream

The attackers didn't just steal data‚Äîthey gained access to lawful intercept systems used by U.S. law enforcement for court-authorized wiretaps. They intercepted audio and text communications from approximately 150 high-profile targets, including then-presidential candidate Donald Trump, vice-presidential candidate JD Vance, and other government officials.

This wasn't a smash-and-grab operation. According to The Record, the attackers maintained persistent access for months, exfiltrating metadata on millions of Americans and demonstrating sophisticated knowledge of U.S. telecommunications infrastructure.

The January 2025 Mandates: A Response to Crisis

In January 2025, under the Biden administration, the FCC responded to Salt Typhoon by invoking Section 105 of the Communications Assistance for Law Enforcement Act (CALEA). The new rules required telecom carriers to:

1. Secure Networks Against Unlawful Access

Carriers were mandated to implement controls preventing unauthorized access to their networks and lawful intercept systems. This wasn't optional‚Äîit was a legal obligation.

2. Develop Cybersecurity Risk Management Plans

Companies had to create formal, written plans addressing how they would identify, assess, and mitigate cybersecurity risks. These plans would be subject to FCC review.

3. Submit Annual Compliance Certifications

Carriers were required to certify annually that they were meeting cybersecurity requirements, creating accountability and enabling regulatory oversight.

These mandates weren't revolutionary‚Äîthey were basic cybersecurity hygiene that should have been required decades ago. But they represented the first time the FCC had used its regulatory authority to mandate specific cybersecurity controls for telecom infrastructure.

The November 2025 Repeal: "Unlawful and Ineffective"

Ten months later, the FCC‚Äînow under Republican leadership with Chairman Brendan Carr‚Äîvoted to eliminate these requirements. According to Cybersecurity Dive, Carr argued that the January rules were "neither lawful nor effective" and that the FCC had misinterpreted its authority under CALEA.

The FCC's Rationale

Chairman Carr and Commissioner Olivia Trusty, who voted for the repeal, made several arguments:

  • Legal Authority - CALEA was designed to ensure law enforcement access to communications, not to mandate general network cybersecurity
  • Industry Cooperation - Telecom carriers have voluntarily strengthened their security through "collaborative engagement" with the FCC
  • Flexibility - Mandated requirements are too rigid and don't account for the diversity of telecom infrastructure
  • Burden - Compliance costs would be excessive and divert resources from actual security improvements

The commission stated that carriers have already implemented accelerated patching, updated access controls, and improved threat-hunting capabilities through voluntary commitments.

The Dissent: "Leaving the Country Less Secure"

Democratic Commissioner Anna Gomez issued a scathing dissent, warning that the repeal would "leave the country less secure." According to The Register, Gomez argued:

"Collaboration alone will not prevent state-sponsored hackers. The FCC is removing the only meaningful effort made in response to the worst telecommunications hack in U.S. history. Voluntary commitments are not enforceable, and without regulatory teeth, there is no guarantee carriers will maintain security investments when budgets tighten."

Senator Maria Cantwell and other lawmakers also urged the FCC against the repeal, expressing concern that it would weaken America's security posture and leave critical infrastructure vulnerable.

Why This Repeal Is Dangerous

From a cybersecurity perspective, this decision is indefensible. Here's why:

1. Voluntary Security Doesn't Work

The history of critical infrastructure security is littered with failures of voluntary approaches. Companies prioritize shareholder value, not national security. Without regulatory requirements, cybersecurity investments are the first to be cut when budgets tighten.

The Salt Typhoon breach itself is proof that voluntary security failed. These carriers had years to secure their networks. They didn't. It took a catastrophic nation-state compromise to force action, and even that action is now being reversed.

2. The Legal Authority Argument Is Weak

While CALEA's primary purpose is ensuring law enforcement access, Section 105 explicitly requires carriers to ensure that their systems are "reasonably secure" from unauthorized access. The January 2025 interpretation was legally defensible‚Äîthe FCC was ensuring that lawful intercept systems couldn't be compromised by foreign adversaries.

The repeal essentially argues that the FCC can mandate backdoors for law enforcement but can't mandate security for those same backdoors. That's absurd.

3. China Is Still in U.S. Telecom Networks

According to Nextgov, cybersecurity experts believe Chinese actors may still have persistent access to some U.S. telecom infrastructure. The Salt Typhoon campaign wasn't a one-time breach‚Äîit was a sustained espionage operation.

Repealing security mandates while adversaries are potentially still in your networks is like removing your home security system because a burglar already broke in. It makes no sense.

4. This Sends the Wrong Signal to Adversaries

China, Russia, North Korea, and Iran are watching. The message this repeal sends is clear: the U.S. is not serious about defending its telecommunications infrastructure. Attack us, and we'll respond with temporary measures that will be reversed as soon as political winds shift.

The Broader Policy Implications

This repeal isn't just about telecom security‚Äîit's about the fundamental question of how the U.S. regulates critical infrastructure cybersecurity.

The Regulatory Pendulum

We're seeing a pattern where cybersecurity regulations are implemented in response to crises, then rolled back when political leadership changes. This creates:

  • Regulatory uncertainty - Companies don't know what will be required long-term
  • Compliance fatigue - Why invest in meeting requirements that might be repealed?
  • Security gaps - Critical periods where protections are removed

The Voluntary vs. Mandatory Debate

The FCC's shift to "collaborative engagement" represents a broader philosophical debate in cybersecurity policy:

Voluntary Approach Advocates argue that:

  • Industry knows its infrastructure best
  • Flexibility allows for innovation
  • Collaboration builds trust and information sharing
  • Mandates are one-size-fits-all and may be counterproductive

Mandatory Requirement Advocates argue that:

  • Critical infrastructure protection is a public good that markets won't provide
  • Voluntary measures create free-rider problems
  • Regulatory requirements ensure baseline security across all providers
  • Enforcement mechanisms are necessary for accountability

The evidence overwhelmingly supports the mandatory approach for critical infrastructure. Voluntary security has failed repeatedly in energy, healthcare, finance, and now telecommunications.

What This Means for National Security

The practical implications of this repeal are severe:

Intelligence Collection Vulnerability

If Chinese actors can access lawful intercept systems, they can identify which Americans are under U.S. law enforcement surveillance. This compromises ongoing investigations and reveals intelligence priorities.

Metadata Exploitation

Even without accessing content, metadata on who communicates with whom, when, and how often is incredibly valuable for intelligence analysis. The Salt Typhoon breach gave China a comprehensive map of U.S. communication patterns.

Infrastructure Targeting

Access to telecom networks enables reconnaissance for future attacks. In a conflict scenario, the ability to disrupt U.S. communications would be a strategic advantage China has been building for years.

Economic Espionage

Telecom access enables theft of intellectual property, trade secrets, and competitive intelligence. The economic damage from sustained telecom compromise is incalculable.

What Should Have Happened Instead

Rather than repealing the January 2025 mandates, the FCC should have:

  1. Strengthened the requirements - Add specific technical controls, incident reporting timelines, and third-party audit requirements
  2. Provided implementation guidance - Work with industry to develop practical compliance frameworks
  3. Established penalties - Create meaningful consequences for non-compliance
  4. Funded compliance support - Help smaller carriers meet requirements through grants or technical assistance
  5. Mandated threat intelligence sharing - Require carriers to share indicators of compromise with each other and government

Instead, we got a complete reversal that leaves U.S. telecommunications more vulnerable than they were before Salt Typhoon.

Recommendations for Organizations

If you're an enterprise relying on U.S. telecommunications infrastructure, here's what you need to do:

1. Assume Your Telecom Provider Is Compromised

Don't trust carrier security. Implement end-to-end encryption for sensitive communications. Use VPNs, encrypted messaging apps, and secure voice solutions that don't rely on carrier infrastructure.

2. Diversify Telecom Providers

Don't put all your critical communications on a single carrier. If one is compromised, you have alternatives.

3. Monitor for Anomalies

Watch for unusual call patterns, unexpected data usage, or suspicious account activity that could indicate compromise.

4. Pressure Your Carriers

Demand transparency about security practices. Include cybersecurity requirements in your contracts. Make security a procurement criterion.

5. Advocate for Better Policy

Contact your representatives. This repeal happened because there wasn't enough public pressure to maintain the mandates. Make cybersecurity a political priority.

The International Perspective

It's worth noting how other countries are handling telecom security:

  • European Union - The NIS2 Directive mandates comprehensive cybersecurity requirements for telecom operators
  • United Kingdom - The Telecommunications Security Act 2021 requires carriers to meet specific security standards
  • Australia - The Security of Critical Infrastructure Act mandates risk management programs for telecom providers

The U.S. is moving in the opposite direction from our allies, creating a security gap that adversaries will exploit.

Conclusion: A Policy Failure with National Security Consequences

The FCC's decision to repeal telecom cybersecurity mandates is a policy failure that will have lasting national security consequences. It prioritizes industry convenience over critical infrastructure protection, relies on discredited voluntary approaches, and sends a dangerous signal to adversaries.

The Salt Typhoon breach demonstrated that U.S. telecommunications infrastructure is vulnerable to sophisticated nation-state attacks. The January 2025 mandates were a minimal, necessary response. Their repeal leaves America more vulnerable than we were before the breach was discovered.

In cybersecurity, we often say that security is a process, not a product. But it's also a commitment. This repeal demonstrates that the U.S. government's commitment to defending critical telecommunications infrastructure is conditional, political, and ultimately unreliable.

China is still in our networks. And we just told them we're not serious about kicking them out.

articles.excerpt: Western Sydney University‚Äôs recent data breach exposes the silent epidemic of third-party cloud vulnerabilities. As institutions move workloads to managed platforms, their digital trust increasingly depends on vendors they can‚Äôt fully see or control.
articles.content:
The Hidden Breach: How Third-Party Cloud Risks Shattered Trust at Western Sydney University

Author: Harish G

Published: November 8, 2025

In the digital age, a university is more than a campus; it is a massive repository of intellectual property, personal data, and research intelligence. On November 2, 2025, Western Sydney University (WSU) became the latest victim in a growing epidemic of higher education data breaches. But this wasn't a simple phishing attack or a ransomware lockout. It was a sophisticated compromise of a third-party cloud environment that exposed the records of 7,500 students and staff, revealing the fragile nature of the modern digital supply chain.

As institutions increasingly migrate critical workloads to managed platforms, they trade control for convenience. The WSU incident serves as a stark warning: you can outsource your infrastructure, but you cannot outsource your risk.

The Anatomy of the Breach

According to the university's official disclosure, the unauthorized access occurred within a Microsoft 365 environment managed by an external IT service provider. The attackers maintained persistent access for nearly four months before detection, exfiltrating a trove of sensitive data including:

  • Student admission records and academic transcripts
  • Staff payroll and tax file numbers
  • Research grant applications and intellectual property
  • Internal disciplinary records

The breach was not detected by the university's internal SOC, but by the Australian Cyber Security Centre (ACSC) during a routine sweep of dark web forums where the data was being auctioned. This "detection lag"‚Äîthe time between compromise and discovery‚Äîaveraged 120 days in 2025 for third-party breaches, a statistic that WSU unfortunately validated.

The Third-Party Cloud Paradox

The core issue at WSU reflects a systemic vulnerability in modern enterprise architecture. Universities, like many corporations, have aggressively adopted a "Cloud First" strategy. They rely on a constellation of vendors for Learning Management Systems (LMS), Student Information Systems (SIS), and email hosting.

However, the security model often fails to scale with this complexity. In WSU's case, the compromised environment was technically "outside" the university's primary firewall perimeter. It was a shadow tenant, managed by a vendor with security controls that were evidently less rigorous than the university's own standards.

The "Shared Responsibility" Trap

Cloud providers like Microsoft operate on a Shared Responsibility Model. They secure the cloud (physical infrastructure, hypervisor), but the customer is responsible for security in the cloud (identity, data, configuration). When a third-party MSP enters the picture, this model fractures further. Who is responsible for configuring Multi-Factor Authentication (MFA)? Who monitors the access logs? In the WSU breach, this ambiguity created a blind spot that attackers exploited.

Why Higher Education is a Prime Target

Cybercriminals target universities for three specific reasons, all of which played a role in the WSU incident:

  1. High-Value Data Diversity: Universities hold PII (like a bank), health records (like a hospital), and IP (like a tech company). This "one-stop-shop" makes them lucrative targets for data brokers.
  2. Open Culture vs. Secure Infrastructure: Academic environments prize openness and information sharing. Imposing draconian Zero Trust controls is culturally difficult, leading to permissive network policies.
  3. Decentralized IT: Departments often spin up their own cloud instances or hire their own vendors without central IT oversight, creating "Shadow IT" sprawl.

Strategic Lessons for CISOs

The WSU breach offers critical lessons for security leaders across all sectors, not just education.

1. Audit Your Digital Supply Chain

You must know every vendor that holds your data. But more importantly, you must know their security posture. Do they enforce MFA? Do they undergo regular penetration testing? Contractual clauses are not enough; you need technical validation.

2. Extend Visibility Beyond the Perimeter

If your data lives in a third-party cloud, your logs should live in your SIEM. Demand that vendors export access logs to your central monitoring platform. You cannot defend what you cannot see.

3. Enforce Least Privilege for Vendors

Third-party accounts should not have standing admin privileges. Use Just-In-Time (JIT) access and Privileged Identity Management (PIM) to ensure that vendor access is temporary, audited, and revoked immediately after the task is complete.

The Road Ahead: Rebuilding Trust

Western Sydney University is now undertaking a massive remediation effort, including mandatory password resets for 45,000 users and a complete architecture review. But the reputational damage is done. For students, the breach is a violation of trust. For researchers, it is a threat to their life's work.

As we move into 2026, the WSU breach will likely be cited as a case study in the failure of third-party risk management. It reminds us that in a hyper-connected world, your security is only as strong as your weakest vendor.

As the trillion-parameter Gemini model begins powering Apple‚Äôs voice assistant through Private Cloud Compute, the question looms: can Apple retain its moral high ground in an age when privacy and intelligence may be mutually exclusive?
articles.content:
Gemini Inside: Can Apple Keep Its Privacy Promise with Google's Brain?

Author: Harish G

Published: November 8, 2025

For over a decade, Apple has marketed privacy not just as a feature, but as a fundamental human right. "What happens on your iPhone, stays on your iPhone." But on November 8, 2025, that promise faced its greatest test. With the release of iOS 19.2, Apple officially integrated Google's Gemini Ultra model into the core of Siri, marking a historic partnership between two Silicon Valley rivals.

The integration brings unprecedented intelligence to the iPhone‚ÄîSiri can now summarize emails, generate creative text, and understand complex context with the power of a trillion-parameter model. But it also raises an uncomfortable question: Can Apple maintain its privacy-first identity when its flagship AI features rely on the world's largest data advertising company?

The Architecture of Compromise: Private Cloud Compute

Apple anticipated this skepticism. To bridge the gap between on-device privacy and cloud-scale intelligence, they unveiled Private Cloud Compute (PCC). This architecture is arguably the most sophisticated privacy engineering feat in modern cloud computing.

How PCC Works

When a user makes a request that is too complex for the on-device Neural Engine (e.g., "Plan a 5-day itinerary for Tokyo based on my emails"), the iPhone strips the request of IP addresses and metadata. It then encrypts the semantic payload using a key that only the PCC node possesses.

The PCC servers run on custom Apple Silicon (M5 Ultra chips) with a hardened, stripped-down OS. Crucially, Apple claims:

  • No Persistent Storage: Data is held in RAM only for the duration of the inference.
  • No Logging: Neither Apple nor Google can see the raw prompt or the response.
  • Verifiable Builds: Security researchers can cryptographically verify the software running on the PCC nodes to ensure no backdoors exist.

The Google Factor: A Marriage of Convenience

Despite PCC, the involvement of Google's Gemini raises eyebrows. Why did Apple, a company with $160 billion in cash, choose to license a competitor's model rather than build its own?

The answer is pragmatism. Training a frontier model like Gemini Ultra requires tens of thousands of H100 GPUs and years of RLHF (Reinforcement Learning from Human Feedback). Apple, having started late in the Generative AI race, faced a choice: release an inferior product, or partner with the best. They chose the latter.

Under the agreement, Google provides the model weights and inference logic, but the execution happens within Apple's controlled PCC environment (or on Google Cloud instances wrapped in Apple's encryption layer). Google does not get to use Apple user data to train Gemini. It is a pure licensing play.

The Privacy Paradox

While the engineering is sound, the optics are messy. Users are confused. When Siri says, "I used Gemini to answer this," does that mean Google knows what I asked? Apple's marketing team is working overtime to explain the nuance of "Private Cloud," but trust is binary. You either have it, or you don't.

The Metadata Leakage Risk

Security researchers point out that even with PCC, side-channel attacks are theoretically possible. Traffic analysis could reveal the type of requests a user is making, even if the content is encrypted. Furthermore, if the integration hands off to Google Search for live data, the privacy shield thins significantly.

Strategic Implications for the AI Ecosystem

This partnership signals the end of the "Walled Garden" era for AI. No single company‚Äînot even Apple‚Äîcan dominate every layer of the AI stack. We are moving towards a modular AI economy:

  • Hardware Layer: Apple (Edge), NVIDIA (Cloud)
  • Model Layer: Google, OpenAI, Anthropic
  • Application Layer: iOS, Android

Apple is positioning itself as the Privacy Broker. They are saying, "We don't build the brain, but we build the helmet that protects your thoughts."

Conclusion: A New Definition of Privacy

The Apple-Google Gemini deal redefines what "privacy" means in 2025. It is no longer about keeping data strictly on-device; that is impossible for modern AI. It is about verifiable, cryptographic control over data in transit and in processing.

If Apple's Private Cloud Compute holds up to scrutiny, it could set a new standard for the industry. If it fails‚Äîif a single leak occurs‚Äîit could shatter Apple's brand value overnight. For now, the iPhone is smarter, but the user must decide if they are comfortable sharing their brain with a ghost in the machine.
